Stay gentle Isis, stay thy silver tide,</br>While I my Lay to doleful tenor turn;</br>With murm'ring pleasance now forbear to glide,</br>And let me teach thy wanton wave to mourn.</br>Forbear sweet breeze to curl adown the stream,</br>While the sad muse pursues her plaintive theme.

Ye feather'd messengers of grateful spring,</br>Let awful silence sit on ev'ry bough,</br>With warbling melody forbear to sing,</br>For joyous note wou'd ill behove ye now.</br>Let gloomy sadness veil the blooming pride</br>Of vari'd mead, and ev'ry flow'ret hide!

Whilom the Muses in beseeming verse</br>On Isis banks pip'd their sweet Roundelays,</br>And Swains were wont their numbers to rehearse,</br>And distant hills return'd their favourite's praise;</br>But now forsaken River now no more</br>The heav'nly Sisters shall frequent your shore.

Where, mournful Maidens, shall the Poet find</br>Sweet images to charm the list'ning throng?</br>Where are the qualities of noble mind</br>That erst gave matter to the grateful song?</br>The Patriot's zeal — the Parent's tender care</br>And Husband's fondness no distinction wear.

Ah me!  how fleeting are a mortal's joys?</br>E'er the full blossom of our comfort's blown,</br>Too-hasty fate with secret hand destroys,</br>And FREDERICK and all our hopes are gone.</br>Help, tragick muse, assist me to devise</br>Notes sad enough to wail our miseries.

Who shall direct you now, ye chearless swains,</br>Himself the foremost to lead on the way?</br>Or rules of sapience teach in tempting strains?</br>Himself the great example of his lay?</br>Who now shall nurse with care the worthy scheme</br>Of liberty, fair Albion's darling theme?

Ye Nymphs, who now shall teach the roving spouse</br>Firm truth, and sweetest durancy of love?</br>Or in whose name shall lovers tell their vows,</br>And swear, like his their plighted faith shall prove?</br>Like his, whose hapless and untimely fate</br>Forlorn AUGUSTA mourns in widow'd state?

Ill wou'd it thee betide unhappy Isle,</br>And greater still wou'd be the cause to moan</br>Shou'd heav'n again withhold her gracious smile,</br>And Royal GEORGE forsake the peaceful throne;</br>Then saddest plaint wou'd reach the farthest shore</br>And gladsome carol ne'er be chanted more.

But tho' our hopes are fled, nor joy of aught</br>To the distemper'd Soul sweet solace brings,</br>Yet let the muse indulge the pleasing thought,</br>That FREDERICK shall yield a race of Kings!</br>Himself tho' dead — his worth may still survive,</br>The Sire remembred in the Son may live.</br>
